awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A New Nonlinear Modal Updating Framework for Soft, Hydrated Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The mechanical properties of soft, hydrated materials have long been of interest to the scientific community. Using soft materials in mechanical designs is becoming increasingly prominent due to their obvious advantages such as flexibility in design and intentional exploitation of nonlinearity. Especially, the high-rate response of soft materials has received attention due to their many applications in robotics, materials and the biomedical sciences. Most soft and hydrated materials (e.g., biomaterials) exhibit complex mechanical behavior that is challenging to quantify due to measurement uncertainties, mechanical anisotropy and inhomogeneity. In this project, a new nonlinear dynamics-based system identification and model updating methodology will be formulated to characterize and model soft, hydrated materials. The findings of this research have the potential to drastically enhance the accuracy, cost-efficiency and accessibility of broadband soft material characterization, and, as such, it can be transformative in diverse interdisciplinary areas, such as soft robotic design, mechanical indentation measurements and soft tissue feedback during surgery. The resulting model updating approach for soft materials will be transformative in predictive engineering designs since it will enable the better utilization and integration of soft materials in diverse applications. This approach can be used for both exploiting the nonlinearities in soft mechanical designs, as well as for their health monitoring. This project will also provide training and mentoring opportunities for a diverse group of K12, undergraduate and graduate students, with a special emphasis on underrepresented groups. Interactive demonstrations of the developed methodology are planned to be displayed in local science festivals to engage the interest of the public in this scientific issue.

The main objective of this project is to introduce a new nonlinear dynamics-based system identification and model updating methodology to characterize soft, hydrated materials. It is based on direct analysis of measured response time series, and construction of appropriately defined transitions in appropriately defined frequency-energy plots (FEPs) of a soft-tissue tester and sample system. The dynamics of an underlying conservative system (i.e., the corresponding system with no dissipative effects) modeling the tester is then correlated with the measured response by computing nonlinear normal modes (NNMs). In the conservative system model, soft tissues are modeled as highly flexible elements with stiffness and damping nonlinearities. Then, the reconciliation of the measured and simulated responses in the FEPs is utilized to estimate the broadband dissipative properties of the soft tissues. The experimental validation will be done by testing soft materials such as tendons, hydrated PDMS and brain tissue. The physics-based nonlinear approach in this study for model updating is unprecedented since it is based exclusively on direct time series analysis, and the framework is sufficiently general to be applicable to other engineering applications, such as the reconciliation of nonlinear finite element models with experimental measurements, and the accurate model reduction of mechanical and aerospace components. Moreover, this research will drastically increase our understanding of complicated dynamical transitions and modal interactions in systems with nonlinear viscoelastic properties. It will also enable predictive engineering design of such systems and will provide new insights into the broadband response of soft materials by developing and applying a uniquely new nonlinear-dynamics based model updating framework.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF THE STEVENS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this work was to study a new model updating framework that is broadly applicable to a broad class of soft materials with nonlinear viscoelastic properties. The research has the potential to enable new understanding of geometrically induced nonlinear effects in such materials; to develop an integrated framework for nonlinear system identification and reduced-order modeling of dynamical systems with soft materials; and to promote a new way for nonlinear model updating of systems with soft materials through reconciliation of computational results and experimental measurements.

Th proposed nonlinear model updating framework was constructed based on using the frequency transitions of empirical time series datasets to create reduced-order models in soft systems. As such, this model updating framework utilized direct analysis of measured response time series, and constructed appropriately defined transitions in the frequency-energy domain. Throughout the project, we considered multiple soft-material system models to test this modal updating framework, including soft gels and biological materials. We were able to successfully characterize nonlinear frequency transitions in the broadband dynamical response of these materials by using wavelet transform (WT). The primary soft-material benchmark systems we considered for this project were the brain-skull system as well as soft padding systems for helmets, consisting mostly of polyurethane foam. As a benchmark for our model updating framework, our goal was to develop and conduct model updating on a nonlinear reduced order model of the human brain-skull system and the soft helmet material during impact. In collaboration with the UIUC team led by Prof. Alexander Vakakis, we proposed a geometrically nonlinear reduced order model (ROM) to closely study the dynamics of the deep white-matter region of the human brain under rotational impact excitation. Stevens team provided the validation dataset for the ROM and helped with simulations. We verified the validity of the proposed ROM by comparing its response to different rotational excitations to the predictions of an advanced and complex finite element model of the entire human brain. We showed that our proposed simplified ROM is capable of demonstrating similar nonlinear behavior as the much more advanced and sophisticated finite element model of the human brain. Next, we implemented a reduced order model of a helmet padding to brain ROM. We then experimentally tested different helmets with different padding properties in terms of stiffness and damping to characterize their effects on the skull response. These results were used to validate the helmet-skull-brain ROM and to further understand the effect of material damping on soft materials. This activity was the pinnacle of the proposed project: We were able to come up with a simplified brain-skull-helmet ROM that can be used for nonlinear model updating purposes, such as testing the effect of different helmet properties in the impact response of the head. The findings of this activity can be used to design and select helmet padding materials.  This research resulted in the development of a simplified, yet accurate dynamical model of the human brain which can be used not only for quick in-field predictive studies, but also is capable of hinting to the link between local, geometrically-induced nonlinear phenomena in the deep white matter region of the human brain.

The findings of this research and the proposed model updating framework have the premise for far-reaching impact, including the potential to drastically increase the accuracy, cost-efficiency and accessibility of broadband soft material characterization, and, as such, it can be transformative in diverse interdisciplinary areas, such as soft robotic design, micro and nanoindentation measurements, soft tissue feedback during surgery, and modeling of the impact dynamics of the brain. Our broader impacts were evident as some of our findings, including soft padding design in helmets, were used in outreach activities for K12 and undergraduate students.


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Mehmet Kurt
